template.name: Template App Golang
template.description: Common template for monitoring Go services via expvar package

item.name: Go Goroutines
item.description: Number of goroutines that currently exist.

item.name: Go HeapInuse
item.description: Bytes in in-use (non-idle) spans. In-use spans have at least one object in them. These spans can only be used for other objects of roughly the same size. HeapInuse minus HeapAlloc estimates the amount of memory that has been dedicated to particular size classes, but is not currently being used. This is an upper bound on fragmentation, but in general this memory can be reused efficiently.

item.name: Go HeapAlloc
item.description: Bytes allocated and not yet freed. Allocated heap objects include all reachable objects, as well as unreachable objects that the garbage collector has not yet freed. Specifically, HeapAlloc increases as heap objects are allocated and decreases as the heap is swept and unreachable objects are freed. Sweeping occurs incrementally between GC cycles, so these two processes occur simultaneously, and as a result HeapAlloc tends to change smoothly (in contrast with the sawtooth that is typical of stop-the-world garbage collectors).

item.name: Go Frees
item.description: Cumulative count of heap objects freed.

item.name: Go HeapIdle
item.description: Bytes in idle (unused) spans. Idle spans have no objects in them. These spans could be (and may already have been) returned to the OS, or they can be reused for heap allocations, or they can be reused as stack memory. HeapIdle minus HeapReleased estimates the amount of memory that could be returned to the OS, but is being retained by the runtime so it can grow the heap without requesting more memory from the OS. If this difference is significantly larger than the heap size, it indicates there was a recent transient spike in live heap size.

item.name: Go Mallocs
item.description: Cumulative count of heap objects allocated.

item.name: Go HeapObjects
item.description: Total number of allocated heap objects. Like HeapAlloc, this increases as objects are allocated and decreases as the heap is swept and unreachable objects are freed.

item.name: Go TotalAlloc
item.description: Cumulative bytes allocated for heap objects (even if freed) throughout the lifetime.

item.name: Go NumForcedGC
item.description: Number of GC cycles that were forced by the application calling the GC function.

item.name: Go NextGC
item.description: Next collection will happen when HeapAlloc > this amount. The garbage collector's goal is to keep HeapAlloc ≤ NextGC. At the end of each GC cycle, the target for the next cycle is computed based on the amount of reachable data and the value of GOGC.

item.name: Go GCTimeNS
item.description: Number of nanoseconds taken to last garbage collection.

item.name: Go NumGC
item.description: Number of completed GC cycles.

item.name: Go Lookups
item.description: Number of pointer lookups performed by the runtime. This is primarily useful for debugging runtime internals.

item.name: Go HeapSys
item.description: Bytes obtained from system. This metric measures the amount of virtual address space reserved for the heap. This includes virtual address space that has been reserved but not yet used, which consumes no physical memory, but tends to be small, as well as virtual address space for which the physical memory has been returned to the OS after it became unused. It estimates the largest size the heap has had.

item.name: Go HeapReleased
item.description: Bytes of physical memory returned to the OS. This counts heap memory from idle spans that was returned to the OS and has not yet been reacquired for the heap.

item.name: Go Sys
item.description: Total bytes obtained from system. Sys is the sum of the XSys metrics. Sys measures the virtual address space reserved by the Go runtime for the heap, stacks, and other internal data structures. It's likely that not all of the virtual address space is backed by physical memory at any given moment, though in general it all was at some point.

item.name: go.expvar.jsondata
item.description: Service item for data retreival

item.name: Go MCacheInuse
item.description: Bytes of allocated mcache structures.

item.name: Go MSpanInuse
item.description: Bytes of allocated mspan structures.

item.name: Go StackInuse
item.description: Number of bytes in stack spans. In-use stack spans have at least one stack in them. These spans can only be used for other stacks of the same size. There is no StackIdle because unused stack spans are returned to the heap (and hence counted toward HeapIdle).

item.name: Go BuckHashSys
item.description: Bytes of memory in profiling bucket hash tables.

item.name: Go GCSys
item.description: Bytes of memory in garbage collection metadata.

item.name: Go MCacheSys
item.description: Bytes of memory obtained from the OS for mcache structures.

item.name: Go MSpanSys
item.description: Bytes of memory obtained from the OS for mspan structures.

item.name: Go OtherSys
item.description: Bytes of memory in miscellaneous off-heap runtime allocations.

item.name: Go StackSys
item.description: Bytes used by stack allocator, and these bytes was obtained from system. StackSys is StackInuse, plus any memory obtained directly from the OS for OS thread stacks (which should be minimal).
